comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Continuing ... He was in the news so often, it's impossible to suggest when the photo was taken. He had been a member of the First Regiment of Volunteer Cavalry (aka Roosevelt's Rough Riders) and figures frequently in the NYT society columns, including those from London. On May 17, 1912 the NYT published an article about a letter apparently written by Harry K. Thaw to a private detective in 1903. The version of the letter published in the New York Herald had a postscript included a list of names (including Craig Wadsworth) with some of them (not Wadsworth, but including Stanford White whom Thaw killed in 1906) annotated with the word "kill." The NYT article [ query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9507E1DA103AE633A... ] reports that the postscript was claimed to be a forgery by Thaw's lawyer. For more on the Thaw case, see www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2929579164/ NYT SOCIETY AT HOME AND ABROAD column on October 13, 1912, Sunday [ query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9504E1DB1F3CE633A... ] reported that Craig Wadsworth was heading for Europe on his way to Teheran to assume position of Secretary of the American Embassy there. He attended US Ambassador Whitelaw Reid's memorial service in London on Dec 20, 1912 and by that time had been appointed to the Bucharest Legation.
